data.title: List of current systems for electric rail traction
data.meta_description: This a list of the power supply systems that are, or have been, used for tramway and railway electrification systems. Note that the voltages are nominal and vary depending on load and distance from the substation. Many modern trams and trains use
data.text:
This a list of the power supply systems that are, or have been, used for tramway and railway electrification systems.

Note that the voltages are nominal and vary depending on load and distance from the substation.

Many modern trams and trains use on-board solid-state electronics to convert these supplies to run three-phase AC induction motors.

Contents

1 Key to the tables below

2 Systems using standard voltages

2.1 Overhead systems

2.1.1 500 V DC

2.1.2 550 V DC

2.1.3 600 V DC

2.1.4 750 V DC

2.1.5 1,500 V DC

2.1.6 3 kV DC

2.1.7 15 kV AC, 16⅔ Hz (16.7 Hz)

2.1.8 25 kV AC, 50 Hz

2.1.9 25 kV AC, 60 Hz

2.1.10 50 kV AC, 50 Hz

2.1.11 50 kV AC, 60 Hz

2.2 Conductor rail systems

2.2.1 600 V DC

2.2.2 750 V DC

3 Systems using non-standard voltages

3.1 Overhead systems

3.2 Conductor rail systems

4 Three-phase systems

5 Special or unusual types

5.1 DC, plough collection from conductors in conduit below track

5.2 DC, one ground-level conductor

5.3 DC, two ground-level conductors

5.4 DC, two-wire

5.5 DC, power from running rails

5.6 DC, four-rail

6 See also

7 References

8 External links

Key to the tables below

Volts: voltage or volt

Current:

DC = direct current

xx Hz = frequency in hertz (alternating current (AC))

AC supplies are single-phase, except where marked three-phase

Conductors:

overhead line or

conductor rail, usually a third rail to one side of the running rails

Conductor rail can be:

top contact: oldest, least safe, affected by ice, snow and leaves

side contact: newer, safer, less affected by ice, snow and leaves

bottom contact: newer, safer, least affected by ice, snow and leaves

Systems using standard voltages

See also: Railway electrification system#Voltage

Voltages are defined by two standards: BS EN 50163 [1] and IEC 60850[2]

This voltage is used for most modern tram systems.
